As the Japanese well know, deflation can be a horrible thing, and at the height of this country's economic woes last year, there was a little evidence of deflation here. Now that evidence has gone.

Vigorous economic growth throughout 1983 has shaken up the rankings of the nation's 25 largest nonfinancial corporations. And, as a result of regulatory changes and merger decisions, the list of America's biggest companies is almost certain to undergo even more dramatic change this year. As in years past, the names of big oil companies continued to dominate the overall rankings in terms of revenues and net income. But after a second consecutive year of soft prices, the petroleum industry's grip on the top spots has weakened.

Although Senator Bob Dole avoids the kind of detailed economic policy debates that President Clinton is known to relish, the all-but-official Republican Presidential nominee nonetheless has a loose grouping of economic advisers who are helping to shape his views and sharpen his message. And they seem likely to play an increasingly important role as Mr. Dole's Presidential campaign develops its economic strategy and formulates more specific positions on issues like how to promote greater growth and end the long stagnation in average wages.

THE robot, that blend of machine tool and computer built to perform t he most humdrum tasks with consistency, has become the key factor int he push toward the manless American factory. In the coming decade, a s companies in the United States forge ahead with computerized m anufacturing, the factory floor will take on ''Star Wars'' overtonesw ith batteries of robots, the so-called steel-collar workers, ' 'manning'' assembly lines. But the labor-saving robot has also created a new, if streamlined, work force: its own technician specialty, capable of low-level programming and reprogramming, monitoring and occasionally repairing the robot's complex anatomy. As corps of robot engineers and computer-software programmers design subsequent generations of robots, these technicians at least for the foreseeable future will maintain the robots actually plugged into the restructured factory landscape.

WASHINGTON HOW thin is the ice President Reagan is skating on? That is the question being asked as he begins a second year in office anxious to continue cutting the influence of the Federal Government but to manage politics and economics in a way that avoids major manage politics and economics in a way that avoids major Republican losses in the 1982 elections. Despite the frigid winter, the ice is getting thinner. His percent in national surveys. Unemployment has reached record levels for an election year and three Americans in ten expect it to hit their families this year, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll. Conservatives are nagging that he has become too much a pragmatist. The Republican unity that formed a precondition of his 1981 successes is strained. But that ice will still support him. Those approval ratings are falling only gradually. Three Americans in five say they think his economic program will eventually succeed, an optimistic group that included half of those who feared unemployment in their family. The President's ability to avoid political damage from his own errors, like those that punctuated Tuesday's press conference, seems as good as ever. The Administration has seriously consulted at least friendly governors about the welfare changes he wants to propose, and the Republicans, like the extra-party conservatives, are likely to find that they have nowhere else to go.

LEAD: COMPANIES A New Game at Trump's Tables Donald J. Trump had better hope he can bargain better than he can run a casino. He failed on Friday to pay about $40 million due on ''junk bonds'' and another $30 million on bank loans that financed his purchase of Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

For more than two years the nation's unemployment rate has hovered around 7 percent, a level long considered intolerably high and far above the 4 percent target set by Federal law. Few analysts, moreover, expect the rate to decline appreciably in the near future, even if the current economic expansion, which is now approaching its fourth anniversary, continues. Yet for all the lost production and individual distress associated with having 8.33 million Americans jobless -more than the population of New York City - a 7 percent unemployment rate seems to have become acceptable to the public, some experts say. This comes after unemployment rates in the double digits from September 1982 through May 1983, reaching a peak of 10.7 percent in December 1982. A Sense of Well-Being The drop in unemployment along with the dramatic decline in inflation, also from the double digits in 1979 and 1980, has done much to restore a sense of economic well-being. Most experts believe that jobs, except where employment has fallen because of highly visible foreign competition, will not be a major campaign issue this year.

Adjusted for inflation, Americans' per-capita income shrank in 1991 for the first time in nine years, the Government said today. Personal income totaled $19,082 a person last year, just 2.1 percent more than in 1990, the Commerce Department said. But that rate was only slightly more than half last year's 4.1 percent inflation rate as measured by the department's index for personal expenditures.

LEAD: It was an unhappy looking group that assembled in the Rose Garden this afternoon. In the politics of the moment, the budget deal does not give any of them, President Bush or the Congressional leaders, a winning hand.

Every once in a while a politician comes up with an idea that's so bad, so wrongheaded, that you're almost grateful. For really bad ideas can help illustrate the extent to which policy discourse has gone off the rails. And so it was with Senator Joseph Lieberman's proposal, released last week, to raise the age for Medicare eligibility from 65 to 67.

Manhattan's only Republican Representative, Bill Green, said last February that if President Reagan's economic program was doing well by election time, he and other Republicans would be clamoring to share credit for it. If it was not working, he added, ''we'll distance ourselves from him.'' Mr. Green has been distancing himself from the Reagan program as he campaigns for a third term in the 15th Congressional District, which runs from lower Manhattan up the East Side, curves west to take in much of midtown south of Central Park and then heads east again and north to roughly 96th Street. The area is known as the ''silk stocking district.''

Investors who buy stock with borrowed money will find that the dividends they get will be taxable even after other dividends are no longer taxed, according to the Bush administration. ''This could have a big impact on people who buy stock on margin,'' David Hariton, a tax partner at Sullivan & Cromwell, said yesterday, a day after the Treasury disclosed its plan to make dividends taxable if they came from ''debt-financed stock.''

It is a question asked repeatedly across America: why, in the aftermath of a financial mess that generated hundreds of billions in losses, have no high-profile participants in the disaster been prosecuted? Answering such a question -- the equivalent of determining why a dog did not bark -- is anything but simple. But a private meeting in mid-October 2008 between Timothy F. Geithner, then-president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Andrew M. Cuomo, New York's attorney general at the time, illustrates the complexities of pursuing legal cases in a time of panic.

The number of houses placed under contract fell sharply in November in the first drop in nearly a year, figures released Tuesday show. It was the clearest sign yet that predictions of another downturn in real estate may become a reality. The National Association of Realtors said that its index of pending home sales plunged to 96 from a revised level of 114.3 in October. Analysts had predicted a drop, but nothing like that.

Poles were jolted last week by the sudden discovery that they were not immune to the financial crisis contagion rippling across the globe. The plunging stock market here and the drastic weakening of the Polish currency proved, as in so many corners of the fast-growing developing world, how wrong they were. The go-go atmosphere in Poland has abruptly stilled to a cautious wait-and-see. Developers across the country have halted building projects for thousands of apartments as banks have grown stingy with lending. The boomtown energy here has been replaced by nervous eyeing of the once powerful zloty, as it retreats in value against the dollar and the euro.

President-elect Ronald Reagan met with his economic advisers today to review proposals for major economic initiatives, and then vowed to do ''what I said throughout the campaign that I was going to do.'' Mr. Reagan did not address specifics, but he referred to a report by his economic policy coordinating committee as ''plans for implementation, reducing the cost of Government, reducing the tax burden on the American people.''

The British unemployment rate rose to 6 percent in October, according to figures released today by the Department of Employment. The figures show a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent, or 32,200 workers, to 1.7 million, from the previous month.

New government data indicate that the concentration of corporate wealth among the highest-income Americans grew significantly in 2003, as a trend that began in 1991 accelerated in the first year that President Bush and Congress cut taxes on capital. In 2003 the top 1 percent of households owned 57.5 percent of corporate wealth, up from 53.4 percent the year before, according to a Congressional Budget Office analysis of the latest income tax data. The top group's share of corporate wealth has grown by half since 1991, when it was 38.7 percent.

Consumer confidence tumbled in February as persistent worries about jobs tarnished Americans' optimism, an industry group reported yesterday. The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index dropped more than 9 points, to 87.3, after a rise in January to a revised reading of 96.4. That reading was the index's highest since mid-2002. Analysts expected a decline, but the index came in significantly below their consensus forecast of 92.3.

No political strategy is considered more potent by Republicans or truer to their core beliefs than promising big tax cuts. In advocating a $548 billion tax cut, Bob Dole has seized an issue that he can use to define his differences with President Clinton, and one that opens the door to a debate over why Americans feel so insecure and overworked despite the economy's solid performance in recent years.

In a small, windowless conference room, the nine members of the management team at Ram Tool gathered to consider which employees should be laid off in the company's latest round of cutbacks. They debated each name and weighed issues like seniority and skills. Could they do multiple jobs? What was their attendance record? Finally, after three days of discussions, they arrived at a list, and it fell to Shelly Polum, the vice president for administration at this small, family-owned tool-and-die manufacturing company here, to inform four workers they were being let go. She put on what her husband called her ''stone-cold face'' and walked out onto the shop floor.

LARRY SUMMERS is taking heat for the way he has handled the bond market. I say it's a bum rap. He just saved the taxpayers a billion dollars while leaving Wall Street baffled. He is the salesman of the year. Consider the situation the Treasury secretary found himself in three weeks ago. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds had climbed to 6.75 percent, and the market value of such bonds was down 9 percent in just two months. Sentiment indicators showed that investors disliked bonds more than at any time since 1987.

Concerned that its latest attempt to be more open might be confusing investors as much as helping them, the Federal Reserve is reviewing its new practice of disclosing once-secret decisions about tilting policy toward raising or reducing interest rates, the central bank said today. The Fed said it had established a committee to study ways to clarify the meaning of the statement the central bank issues at the conclusion of each policy meeting. Since May, the Fed has used the statement not only to disclose any immediate changes to monetary policy, but also to say whether it had adopted a ''bias,'' a formal decision that it sees a possible need to raise or lower rates in the near future.

The domestic steel industry, despite interest rate declines that have eased carrying costs for both producers and customers, is still in sorry shape. ''There are no signs of recovery anywhere,'' said Charles Bradford, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.

WASHINGTON BETWEEN now and Election Day this November, the country will learn whether the conservative Administration headed by President Reagan is really going to pursue a conservative fiscal policy - and, if it does, whether it can persuade Congress to come along. Mr. Reagan won bruising budget-cutting battles in Congress last year, but not one of his lieutenants, nor any outside analyst, suggests that the seemingly self-willed growth of Federal spending has been brought under control. Achieving such control is regarded by Reaganites as an end in itself - a view that was emerging in the waning months of the Democratic Carter Administration. But Mr. Reagan is learning that getting there without doing violence to other priorities and political alliances is no easy matter. Republican Senators rebelled last fall when he sought $8 billion in discretionary spending cuts on top of the $35 billion cut earlier.

The Democratic response to the economic crisis has its problems, but let's face it, the current Republican response is totally misguided. The House minority leader, John Boehner, has called for a federal spending freeze for the rest of the year. In other words, after a decade of profligacy, the Republicans have decided to demand a rigid fiscal straitjacket at the one moment in the past 70 years when it is completely inappropriate. The G.O.P. leaders have adopted a posture that allows the Democrats to make all the proposals while all the Republicans can say is ''no.'' They've apparently decided that it's easier to repeat the familiar talking points than actually think through a response to the extraordinary crisis at hand.

BUSINESS jets are a force for good. Really. This may seem like an outrageous statement, especially right after the public hubbub that caused Citigroup -- the beneficiary of billions in government bailout money -- to cancel the delivery of a new $42 million jet.

Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. went to China with a team of heavyweights, including an array of Bush administration cabinet members and the Federal Reserve chairman. But he is returning home to a more critical audience that is unlikely to be satisfied with the inconclusive results he achieved in opening a new economic dialogue with Beijing.

Spending on building construction declined a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in September, although construction spending for housing continued to rise as interest rates declined, the Commerce Department reported today. The September decrease, to an annual, seasonally adjusted rate of $229.8 billion, was coupled with a revision in the August figures. They were adjusted to a six-tenths of 1 percent rise, to an annual rate of $230.2 billion. The August performance had been estimated earlier at a rise of 1.6 percent.

The asset value of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation fell around 20 percent, to $38.7 billion at the end of last year, but the foundation -- the world's largest philanthropic organization -- will increase its giving this year to $3.8 billion, from $3.3 billion in 2008, Mr. Gates said Monday. ''Although spending at this level will reduce the assets more quickly, the goal of our foundation is to make investments whose payback to society is very high rather than to pay out the minimum to make the endowment last as long as possible,'' Mr. Gates wrote in his first letter as a full-time philanthropist.

IT IS NOT only the Soviet Union that evaporated in 1991. So too did the concept of economic cooperation among the leading Western economies. That became clearer than ever last week, as the German central bank turned its back on the interests of most of Europe, let alone the United States, and jacked up interest rates. The Bundesbank's surprisingly strong move left its discount rate at 8 percent, or more than double the 3.5 percent rate that this country's Federal Reserve adopted as it cut its rate by a point on Friday.

There was plenty of talk about hard-core economic issues like productivity, technology and stock market valuations today at the White House as President Clinton served as the host to a daylong conference on the new economy and what it means for the nation's future. On that level, it broke no new ground. But it was the kind of day Mr. Clinton loves and excels at, rich in policy debate and statistics.

The Producer Price Index, led by declines in gasoline and home heating oil prices, fell 1 percent in January, the largest monthly decrease since the index was started in 1947, the Labor Department reported today. ''Literally, it is remarkable news,'' said Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. ''What it represents is the first taste of what falling oil prices can do for our inflation. It means that inflation is under control and will stay down.''

The Government's index of leading economic indicators declined in March for the 11th consecutive month, falling five-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today. The drop in the index, which is designed to forecast recessions and recoveries, is another signal that the recession is continuing as the economy enters the second quarter, some economists said. Coming in the week of the breakdown of budget negotiations between the White House and Congress, the decline added to the pessimism in the outlook of some forecasters. Orders Up for Factory Goods The Commerce Department also reported that new orders for factory goods edged up by two-tenths of 1 percent in March. (Page 34.)

The stock market fell on Thursday after some doubts emerged over whether the Federal Reserve was ready to take further steps to stimulate the economy. Signs of economic weakness in China and the continuing European debt crisis also weighed on the market.

The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell by $2.3 billion in the week ended June 16, to $452.5 billion. Analysts said the larger-than-expected decline was particularly welcome because it might ease the upward pressure on interest rates at a time when the Treasury was planning to raise $18.6 billion in the credit markets between next Monday and July 5. The Federal Reserve also announced a revision of the money supply figure it had announced for the previous week. It said that, for the week ended June 9, M-1, which measures currency in circulation and funds in all checking accounts at banks and thrift institutions, rose by $1.8 billion instead of the $1.4 billion reported earlier, to a seasonally adjusted $454.8 billion.

AS the United States dollar continues to climb to record heights against foreign currencies, the nation's trade deficit continues to worsen. The Commerce Department reported this week that, in the second quarter of this year, the United States balance of payments on current account rose to a record deficit of $24.4 billion. The current account figures include trade not only in merchandise but also in services, tourism and earnings on foreign investment. With the dollar still rising, the current account balance now seems sure to climb well above $100 billion for the year as a whole, all of which needs to be financed by borrowing from abroad.

Wall Street scored a fifth straight gain and the Dow Jones industrials achieved their third straight record close yesterday after the Labor Department said falling gas prices helped push inflation down last month. Oil prices that plunged to their lowest level in a year added to the advance.

Two recent price reports appear to signal that the hated scourge of inflation may be on the rise. Consumer prices, the government reported yesterday, rose at about a 5 percent annual rate last month, and at a 4 percent rate over the last three months -- about 50 percent faster than in the recent past. Wholesale prices did even worse, rising at about a 10 percent rate in September and at a 7.5 percent rate for the last three months. Will rising inflation force the Federal Reserve to slam on the monetary brakes and bring the bountiful economy to a threateningly slow gait? Almost certainly not. Recent price spikes remain well within the range that the Federal Reserve can handle without punishing the economy.

President Clinton's economic address to a joint session of Congress will be televised live starting at 9 o'clock tonight on CBS (Channel 2 in New York), NBC (Channel 4), ABC (Channel 7), C-Span, CNN and PBS (Channel 13), followed by the Republican response. The speech will also be broadcast live on National Public Radio.

Demonstrating once again its election-year political sensitivity, Congress has begun reacting to the spreading fear that the American dream of homeownership is in serious jeopardy. The Senate last week approved by a wide margin a five-year program that would provide almost $5.1 billion in mortgage subsidies for lowand moderate-income families. The Senate's differences with the House, which had passed a similar measure, will have to be resolved after Congress' Memorial Day recess. Even if President Reagan carries through with last week's warning that he might veto bills containing what he called ''a bailout for one sector,'' these proposals almost certainly represent the emergence of a lively middle-class economic issue with political implications for this autumn's elections, for the new Congress that convenes in January and for the Reagan Administration. ''There isn't a shred of doubt in my mind that this is a frontburner economic issue,'' said Representative Les AuCoin, a Democrat from Oregon. His state's lumber industry has been hard hit by the housing slump, and he was co-author of the mortgage subsidy proposal that the House passed May 12. ''It is a boil-over consumer issue and it is a boil-over jobs issue,'' he said.

LEAD: President Bush's decision last week to limit offshore drilling demonstrates that hardly any politician can risk being seen as anti-environmental. The reason for this is the growth of the environmental consciousness among the American people.

The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, whose sales tumbled despite deep discounts and extended store hours, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession. Sales fell across the board, knocking down once seemingly invincible chains like Target (down 5 percent compared with last year); Abercrombie & Fitch (2 percent); Nordstrom (4 percent); and Kohl's (11.4 percent).

President Bush sought today to strike a cautious new balance in his public remarks about the economy, apparently mindful of recent statements that experts say helped send a key barometer of the stock market skidding by more than 160 points in two sessions of trading over the last five days. In a brief interview with reporters for six NBC-owned television stations, the President called the economy "sluggish," but declined to emphasize either its best or worst aspects.

THE drop in industrial production by half a percentage point in August implies that unemployment, which has held at 9.8 percent of the labor force for the last two months, is likely to rise above 10 percent before the November elections. The drop in production also lowers the rate of industrial capacity utilization, putting additional pressure on capital spending by business. For August, factory use declined to 69.4 percent, off half a percentage point from the low July level. Under the impact of excess capacity, industry has been cutting its capital appropriations steeply. Alan Greenspan of Townsend-Greenspan notes that, excluding highly volatile petroleum expenditures, manufacturers slashed their capital appropriations 17 percent in the second quarter and 34 percent in the last three quarters. Actual capital spending seems to have some way still to fall.

IT is no great puzzle why young male workers have had to run so hard over the last 15 years simply to stay in place. They are the first generation to compete with women workers on a nearly equal basis. More important, they are the first postwar generation to enter the labor market when labor productivity was barely growing. The mystery is why, in spite of the triumphs of the civil rights movement, young black men have lost ground to their white counterparts during the period.

WASHINGTON -- The Obama administration warned Congress on Thursday that the government would reach its legal borrowing limit as early as the end of March and no later than May 16 and urged House and Senate leaders to move quickly to raise the debt ceiling to avoid an unprecedented default. The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, sent a formal notification to Capitol Hill a day after a new Congress convened with Republicans now holding a majority in the House and a larger minority in the Senate, and with many of the newcomers pledged to vote against any increase in the debt limit.

The current economic recovery is nearly six years old, and the annual inflation rate is a meager 3.2 percent -- the lowest level since World War II for an expansion this old. Economists are coming up with all sorts of explanations for the unusual milestone. And gradually many are concluding that inflation has become harder to explain. The most striking aspect of this milestone is the scramble it is provoking among economists to repair the theory that they use to link unemployment and inflation. The theory, a keystone of economic policy, says that when the unemployment rate falls below a certain flash point, inflation soon accelerates. But the flash point foreseen in theory, 6 percent, was breached months ago, and nothing happened. The unemployment rate went as low as 5.1 percent, and still nothing happened.

The federal bailouts of the last few months raise a variety of thorny questions, including who benefits at whose expense. But the question that hits home the hardest is the one that isn't getting enough discussion around kitchen tables: Will we have to bail out our own family members?

The National Bureau of Economic Research said today that it would probably identify a month between June and September 1990 as the beginning of a recession. The private research organization is used by the Government as the official arbiter of dates for peaks and troughs in the business cycle.

It was like a rerun from the 1980 Reagan campaign: The tall, athletic figure standing beside a huge cargo vessel, face wreathed in a characteristic lopsided grin as he placed a hard hat on his head and waved to a crowd of longshoremen. ''America's economy is ready to lead the world out of recession and into recovery,'' he declared as the workers cheered. But President Reagan on the campaign stump in the port of Long Beach, Calif., earlier this month was, in fact, very different from Candidate Reagan of two years ago. Back then, he joyously lashed President Carter and the Democrats for causing the nation's economic stagnation. Now, with the economy still floundering, Mr. Reagan finds his own policies under attack. The very day of his appearance at the shipyard, the Labor Department reported that unemployment had reached 10.1 percent, the highest level since the Great Depression. Republican Congressmen fear that the economic malaise will drag them down to a crushing defeat in the election next month, threatening the future viability of the Reagan Administration itself. No economist lays the entire blame for the current recession at the doorstep of Reaganomics. But judged on its own terms, Mr. Reagan's allegedly painless means to economic recovery has failed to deliver on its promise of simultaneous low inflation, robust growth and a balanced budget.

The economic recovery that almost everyone thought would start with a crawl could begin with a dash instead, according to a growing minority of forecasters, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. But a fast start -- which Fed officials now describe as a reasonable, albeit an unlikely, possibility -- would not presage a sustained boom.

THE roughly 76 million baby boomers, raised to expect lives of unlimited possibilities, start turning 50 tomorrow. And as their future becomes their now, the older boomers are beginning to gray and wrinkle, to wear bifocal contact lenses, to marvel at how young the police are -- and to discover that while many of them will live long, few will prosper. As a group, boomers earn so much that whole industries -- cars being the most expensive example -- made themselves over to win their business. But as individuals, most boomers struggle from paycheck to paycheck, even when there are two breadwinners.

Today's college students, horrified by the corporate bloodletting of the 1980's and early 90's, have set their ambitions higher than working for a good company: They now want to own the company. That is the premise of the Harvard Entrepreneurs Club's ''Guide to Starting Your Own Business,'' edited by Poonam Sharma, that is just now hitting the bookstores. ''We're afraid of being replaceable,'' said Ms. Sharma, a Harvard senior. She is not above chiding her generation for impatience -- saying too many young people yearn to be overnight millionaires -- but she believes that those willing to put in 5 to 10 years in the trenches will be the corporate chiefs of tomorrow.

The National Association of Purchasing Management has been publishing a monthly business survey for the last 50 years, missing only four months during World War II. The association says it has been more reliable in forecasting economic trends than the Commerce Department and the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Its promoters say the association owes this success to simplicity and the confidentiality it assures the more than 200 purchasing managers in 40 states who participate in the survey. Results of the latest survey were released last week.

Steel production rose to 1.831 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.820 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Her thick blue binder in hand, Diane Balaguer strides purposefully through the department store in the Concord Mall north of town. She checks the price of a women's pullover (short sleeve, solid color, no design) eyes a Hastings & Smith polo shirt, notes the seasonal absence of men's turtlenecks and then confronts the day's first challenge to statistical perfection. Ms. Balaguer shakes her head slightly as she regards a rack of Towne raincoats, a style in the London Fog line (tagged at the same $99.90 as the month before). She considers Towne to be of slightly, almost imperceptibly, lesser quality than the Severn line (costing about twice as much) that they replaced this year. It's a matter of things like stitching and buttons.

Adding to a chorus of concern that the United States is losing its edge as the leading financial center, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release a report today urging the country to take a series of steps to improve its legal and regulatory environment. If not, the report warns, it could lose 4 to 7 percent of the global financial services market over the next five years.

Eager to strike a patriotic chord, the House passed a bill this week to offer old-fashioned war bonds for the first time since World War II. The Treasury Department, though, is reluctant to support the measure because it fears the bonds will encourage saving and discourage spending, making it harder for the country to recover from the recession many economists now say has begun.

Prices paid to farmers for raw food products dropped 3.1 percent in December and for the fifth consecutive month averaged below levels a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reported today. Over all, the monthly farm price index did not rise once in 1981, the first time that has happened in nearly half a century, according to department records. As a result of declining prices for farm products, the 1981 ''parity ratio,'' a measure of farmers' buying power, averaged 61 percent over the entire 12 months, according to preliminary estimates. That was the lowest since the indicator averaged 58 percent in 1932, in the depths of the Depression.

CALL it an exercise plan for institutional investors. The Clinton Administration wants to help pension funds flex their financial muscles. These funds are the stewards of more than $4.8 trillion in workers' money. When they act like canny owners, they lift prospects not just for their many beneficiaries; the whole economy is helped.

Following is a transcript of President Bush's State of the Union Message last night at the Capitol, as recorded by The New York Times: Mr. President and Mr. Speaker and members of the United States Congress, I come to this house of the people to speak to you and all Americans, certain that we stand at a defining hour.

Airports around the country broke ground on dozens of projects over the last decade, including new runways and terminals, to handle all the new passenger traffic that seemed certain to keep growing. Now, many of those new developments are being completed. And the timing could not be worse.

EVEN the decorating world is acknowledging the recession, in an oblique way. Signs of tight finances, if no lack of fantasy, can be detected at Show house 91 in Smithtown, L.I., a benefit for Family Service League of Suffolk County that opens Monday. Gold-plated faucets, faux fur upholstery and other 80's extravagances are absent. In their place are vintage sports equipment, bird cages and other relatively inexpensive relics as well as sleights of hand, like a table made of suitcases and shade pulls made of Christmas balls.

AT first sight, the new official data on the economy's growth last year look disappointing. The gross national product, adjusted for inflation, grew 2.3 percent, although, on a fourth-quarter to fourth-quarter basis, the increase was 2.5 percent. That was still a sharp slowdown from the gain of 6.6 percent in 1984. The downward revision of last year's fourth-quarter growth rate to 2.4 percent from the earlier estimate of 3.2 percent raises doubts about whether the economy will reach the 4 percent gain the Administration is forecasting for 1986.

CAMPAIGN '96 Promises, Promises Bob Dole, at last the official Republican nominee, played that old theme song, promising to ''get the economy moving again.'' In his acceptance speech, after discussing values like family and duty, he moved on to the good stuff: lower taxes, zippy growth, a balanced budget, lots more spending on the military, down with the I.R.S., up with the I.R.A. And one thing is sure: The White House in a Dole era wouldn't be populated by those lib kids at home there now, that boomer elite, as Mr. Dole said, ''who never grew up, never did anything real, never sacrificed, never suffered and never learned.'' Not like their daddies. INFLATION ALERT What Blips Up Can Blip Down Traders woke from a sleepy August week to panic briefly on a report of a blip in consumer prices. They were up three-tenths of a percentage point in July, lifting inflation for the past 12 months to a whopping 3 percent. That and a report of strong retail sales, suggesting a heated-up economy, sent interest rates higher and stocks lower. Later, the Federal Reserve restored the status quo, saying industrial production edged up a mere one-tenth of a point in July, the smallest amount in four months. And new housing construction fell to the slowest level in four months. All that allowed traders to sneak off for their Friday golf dates. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week about where it began, at 5,689.45 points, up 8 points. BUY AND HOLD DEPT. Buffett Is It Warren Buffett is America's second-richest man, in fact the world's second-richest man, according to Forbes magazine, which is to the super-rich what People magazine is to Gwyneth Paltrow and Matthew McConaughey. (The wealthiest individual, of course, is that Microsoft fellow out West who defined geek chic.) When Forbes checked in last month, Mr. Buffett had added $4.6 billion to his net worth in the last year, or $125,000 a day, every day of the year, including Feb. 29. But even brilliant stock-pickers suffer reversals. The shares of his investment vehicle Berkshire Hathaway have fallen 14 percent since their high in March, and earnings slipped in the second quarter. Perhaps the market agreed with Mr. Buffett's candid assessment in Berkshire's annual report that the company's market price had grown even faster than its intrinsic value. The stock won big on a doubling in Coca-Cola's stock price. (Berkshire's Coca-Cola shares are now worth $10 billion, or 42 percent of its stock holdings.) Even if Coke's big run is over, Mr. Buffett's composure isn't likely to suffer. When he buys, he typically holds, and then holds some more. ENGLISH 101 And Watch Your P's and Q's Suffolk County, on eastern Long Island, is going to vote on a measure to pick an official language, deciding that would insure economic advancement. It follows the lead of 23 states and 15 cities that have picked an official language. But the vote will not be a multiple choice -- a) Chinese, b) Farsi, c) English. Actually, that choice was already made by county legislators. One said, ''If people want to partake of the American dream they have to know the language.'' Opponents say the county is overreacting to the 1.2 percent of its population of Hispanic origin who speak limited or no English. Whether or not the measure is the right dose of medicine, it is true that people ''who know English do a lot better in their earnings and employment,'' said George Borjas, professor of public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. PICKING UP ROOTS Where Exactly Is Wall St.? If the Big Board moves off Wall Street, what becomes of Wall Street? Perhaps it doesn't matter, because the street is less an address than a metaphor, like Detroit, which people refer to as the focus of the automobile universe even while car plants spring up in Kentucky. Still, the idea of Wall Street without the New York Stock Exchange takes some getting used to. The exchange, which has been at 11 Wall since 1903, is beginning to cast about for bigger quarters to accommodate a much-enlarged trading floor for the electronic era. It intends to stay somewhere in Manhattan, though not necessarily downtown. Tough luck, Jersey City. BROWSER WARS And in This Corner . . . Compared to Netscape, Microsoft is in the uncharacteristic role of underdog, a position it does not want to get used to. The Netscape Navigator Internet browser is used by more than 85 percent of computer users for viewing pages on the World Wide Web. Microsoft is rushing to catch up with its Explorer browser, and the marketing war has begun. Microsoft's new version, available free on the Net, gives away subscriptions through Dec. 31 to the Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition, which normally costs $49 a year, and to the ESPNet Sportszone, which usually charges a la carte. ''If you look at how Microsoft built their franchise in operating systems, it was by adding applications and locking people in,'' said David Smith of the Gartner Group. ''Now content is the application.'' MEDICAL SCHOOLS Tune In, Drop Out Medical students pay much money to attend Cornell University Medical College -- except when Cornell pays them to stay out. Granted, it's a cockeyed arrangement, but Cornell somehow overbooked the incoming class by 15 percent. That forced the school to offer a one-time-only sale -- a tuition-free year, worth $24,000. It is available to doctors-in-waiting willing to put off enrollment a year. A few signed up, but others, ever rational, figured that even a big discount was outweighed by the loss of a year's future earnings, and that's real money in a most lucrative profession. While Cornell and other schools are bulging, some specialists say American schools are turning out too many doctors. MUTUAL FUNDS A Marketing Advantage Fidelity Investments intends to set up an insurance company to protect investors in its money market mutual funds in case of default by any of the security issuers. It would provide coverage of up to $100 million, a relatively small amount in light of Fidelity's $80 billion of assets. But that could be enough to give the company a big marketing advantage. TECHNOLOGY A Star Dims Hewlett-Packard fulfilled predictions of a down quarter, ending years of above-average growth that made it one of the country's most-admired companies. Earnings fell 26 percent in the second quarter, and the company said some of its profit constraints could continue. ''Our PC growth continues at or above the industry growth rate,'' Hewlett said. ''But it is slower than when we were rapidly gaining market share.'' But Dell Computer, another technology leader, surpassed expectations, with earnings growing 58 percent. It enjoyed strong sales and lower chip prices.

To the Editor: Hispanic households are no doubt in the aggregate struggling (front page, Jan. 30). However, I am distressed by the statement made by Arturo Vargas, the head of the National Association of Latino Elected Officials. Mr. Vargas says that Hispanic residents are ''caught in jobs like gardener, nanny and restaurant worker . . . from which they will never advance.''

American consumers, often portrayed as fecklessly mired in high-cost debt, appear to be saying enough is enough. Their automobile, credit card and other installment debt, which excludes mortages, rose just 4.7 percent last year, compared with 6.9 percent in 1996 and 14.2 percent in 1995.

What do you get when you cross a godfather with a Federal Reserve chairman? Someone who makes you an offer you can't understand. Sorry; an old joke, and one that's somewhat unfair to Alan Greenspan. Still, the Fed chairman does talk in a code that, while usually easy to decipher, bears only a distant resemblance to English. Moreover, he has a weakness for Delphic statements, seeming to imply that he knows more than he chooses to say clearly.

Producer prices for finished goods rose slightly in July, the first such increase in three months, according to government data released on Tuesday, helping to ease some concerns about the possibility of deflation. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index rose 0.2 percent last month, compared with a 0.5 percent decline in June. Prices for finished foods, excluding volatile food and energy prices, rose 0.3 percent, exceeding forecasts of 0.2 percent. The price rise of the core index was the largest gain since January.

The Economy The Producer Price Index had its biggest one-month drop since it began being compiled in 1947. The inflation gauge tumbled 1.6 percent in February, largely from the decline in oil and gasoline prices. The drop was much steeper than expected and put the index for finished goods below its February 1985 level. Analysts said that, for now and the forseeable future, there is an absence of inflation in the American economy. [ Page 1. ] Industrial production plunged 0.6 percent in February, the sharpest drop since the end of the last recession. [ 34. ] Business inventories climbed 0.7 percent in January, the biggest increase in 16 months. [ 34. ] An agreement to delay some of the municipal-bond restrictions in the tax-revision bill was reached. The House-passed bill would have become effective retroactively to Jan. 1. The agreement calls for the restrictions to go into effect by Sept. 1 or the date the bill is enacted, whichever is earlier. Analysts expected the agreement to produce only a mild upturn in municipal bond activity. [ 33. ]

Everything about the American economy is down lately: manufacturing production, overall growth and, needless to say, stocks. So why is the dollar still rising? At the beginning of last year, when everything seemed to be going right for the U.S. economy, the dollar was worth less than one euro, and only slightly more than 100 yen. Now everything has gone wrong -- but the euro is below 90 cents and a dollar buys 125 yen.

To the Editor: The foundation for most of Peter G. Peterson's "Hard Truths for Better Days" (Op-Ed, Dec. 1) is an almost universally accepted but increasingly flawed view of how the economy works and ought to work. Briefly, the core "truth" is the old saw that rising production will solve the problems of unemployment and poverty just as a rising tide lifts all boats.

LEAD: There has been no end of anguish recently about the philosophy of greed that, armed with the unofficial blessing of the Reagan Administration, seems to have invaded a distressingly large number of our institutions, from Wall Street to the electronic ministry.

Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the economy's slide was drawing to an end and that the central bank needed to be especially cautious before deciding to try to hasten recovery through another round of interest-rate cuts. "The evidence suggests that the economy is still modestly moving lower, but moving at a reduced rate," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee. "We do expect the bottom to occur within a reasonably short period ahead," he added. "Week by week, the daily numbers still indicate that there is a modest decline." Sign of Economic Weakness Mr. Greenspan's comments came shortly after the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured durable goods tumbled 6.2 percent in March, a considerably worse decline than expected. This was the fourth decline in five months and the biggest since an 11.2 percent plunge in November. The drop in orders for durables -- goods from bicycles to bombers that are expected to last at least three years -- was widespread. When military orders, a volatile category, are excluded, the decline was still a steep 5.4 percent. Shipments and order backlogs also fell. Mr. Greenspan, appearing before the committee to discuss banking and deposit insurance issues, was not asked specifically about the durable goods figures, which he presumably had seen. 'Our Options Are Open' But when asked by Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat who heads the committee, whether interest rates would fall further, Mr. Greenspan, shunning direct comment, said, "We're looking at the economy on a day-by-day basis -- and I would say our options are open." At another point, he seemed to hint at the possibility of lower rates in response to a question about inflation, which ran at a relatively rapid pace early this year before subsiding in March. "Do I see inflationary pressures in price levels and wage levels? I think we're doing rather well in that respect," he said. On the other hand, Mr. Greenspan warned that the risks of a wrong monetary policy decision are magnified at economic turning points, implying it would take more than poor durable-goods orders to prompt another rate cut. "The issue of inflation is that it never surfaces visibly until it is well advanced," the chairman said. In sharp contrast to the guarded statements of Mr. Greenspan, some private analysts used strong language to characterize the latest drop in durables orders, which have fallen to the lowest point since August 1987. Douglas P. Handler, manager of economic analysis at Dun & Bradstreet, called the figures "a horrible setback" to those who believe the economy has already begun to revive, based mainly on some housing data. "The magnitude of this drop-off is usually associated with the beginning of a recession rather than the end," Mr. Handler said. At an annual rate of $110.3 billion, which is adjusted for seasonal variation but not for inflation, orders for durables stand $7.3 billion, or 6.2 percent, below the February pace. The negligible February decline was revised to two-tenths of 1 percent from three-tenths of 1 percent. Among major industries, the biggest loss was a 10.8 percent drop in transportation equipment, with orders weakest for aircraft and parts. Electronic and other electrical machinery dropped 11.8 percent, roughly offsetting a February advance, while primary metals fell 2.6 percent. The exception was industrial machinery and equipment, which edged up seven-tenths of 1 percent. Within capital goods industries, new orders for nonmilitary goods fell 10.3 percent -- 5.5 percent not counting aircraft and parts. New orders for military capital goods fell 16.9 percent, the Commerce Department report also showed. Shipments Also Decline Meanwhile, shipments of durables fell for the fifth straight month, the 2.4 percent decline, to $114.7 billion, dragging them to the lowest level since February 1988. All major industries posted declines, the biggest a 3.9 percent drop for transportation equipment. Unfilled orders, a particularly good economic predictor, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, to $502.3 billion, with all major industries declining here as well. New durables orders last month were 15.4 percent lower than in March 1990, the department also said.

When you pay home heating oil bills this winter, pump gasoline into the family car or buy airline tickets to a sunny climate, you will see just how much OPEC's game of chicken is costing consumers. With OPEC vowing to continue restraints on production, oil prices have begun surging again in the last two weeks. The price of crude oil is now $29.20 a barrel and headed to $30 or more, many commodity analysts say. Gasoline prices are at 77.33 cents a gallon in the futures market and heading to over $1.30 at the pump. And the near-term home heating oil futures contract is up to 86.46 cents a gallon, after climbing 8.6 percent yesterday. All these prices, except gasoline at the pump, are the highest since the run-up to the Persian Gulf war in January 1991.

The Government index that is intended to forecast upturns and downturns in the economy fell 2.7 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported today. The drop in the index of leading economic indicators was the largest monthly decline since last year's recession and was more evidence that the nation's economy is again in a recession. The index measures business activity that leads the general trend of the business cycle by several weeks. Last month's decline in the index was the fourth in the last five months and the largest since a 4 percent drop in April 1980, near the low point of last year's short but steep recession. The index fell five-tenths of 1 percent in August after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in July.

Christmastime is bonus time on Wall Street, and the Gucci set has been blessed with another record harvest. Forget the turbulence in the financial markets and the subprime debacle. Forget the dark clouds of a possible recession. Bloomberg News tells us that the top securities firms are handing out nearly $38 billion in seasonal bonuses, the highest total ever.

The meeting could have been at any number of corporations across the country. Everyone present sat at tables around an LCD projector with their laptops open. But the setting was a church conference room, not a board room, and the spreadsheets under discussion focused not on work but the lack of it. They documented how many hours each person had devoted the previous week to looking for a job.

Health care may be a costly drag on the economy, but it's still a great place to find a job. Midcareer managers and other workers have been migrating to health care jobs for years, of course. Now, with the recession, the lure is even stronger. Hospitals, which employ more than four million people, added 135,000 jobs last year and 19,400 more in the first half of 2009, even as millions of American workers wound up unemployed.

John Kenneth Galbraith, the iconoclastic economist, teacher and diplomat and an unapologetically liberal member of the political and academic establishment he often needled in prolific writings for more than half a century, died Saturday at a hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 97. Mr. Galbraith lived in Cambridge and at an ''unfarmed farm'' near Newfane, Vt. His death was confirmed by his son J. Alan Galbraith.

The Federal Reserve must keep up its anti- inflation fight if the nation is to continue attracting the foreign capital needed for the United States trade and budget deficits, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today. In a speech to the 13th American- German Biennial conference, Mr. Volcker said the United States had no satisfactory alternative for prolonging the flow of capital into the nation because neither deficit will disappear overnight.

Supplies of key petroleum products followed normal seasonal patterns in the week ended Dec. 25, with inventories of distillate falling and gasoline stocks rising, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the same time, however, crude oil imports declined to 3.1 million barrels daily - the lowest of the year - from 4.4 million barrels in the previous week and 5.1 million barrels a year earlier.

THE decline and fall of global economies has not stopped Christophe Decarnin from charging $1,500 for a Balmain T-shirt. That's his cheapest T-shirt. As in a cotton T-shirt, the only distinguishing characteristics being some artfully placed holes. Sparkles will cost you $3,000. A fashion director from a top New York specialty store, shopping the Paris collections this month, questioned the wisdom of stocking up on Balmain after visiting the company's showroom, where the price range of fanciest dresses is $12,000 to $22,000, and jackets are priced at about $5,000. Like pretty much every other retailer, she wanted to carry one of the hottest labels in town, but really now, an entire outfit would cost modest 401(k) holders the equivalent of their losses during last week's market chaos.

What would a visit from the President of the United States be like without a banner welcoming him to town? To her horror, Kate Hinz-Shaffer almost found out. Ms. Hinz-Shaffer, the owner of Riverwood Signs here, was tapped late Thursday morning to provide the 20-foot-by-4-foot royal blue banner that would be draped on the curtain behind President Clinton as he spoke at the Haviland Middle School today about his economic program.

WASHINGTON - Representatives of the Republican and Democratic parties went on television on Sunday morning to blame the other side for Standard & Poor's unprecedented decision to downgrade the credit rating of the United States - a decision that was based largely on a lack of faith in the ability of the political system to forge agreements to reduce the debt.

The acting director of the National Institutes of Health begged university administrators on Wednesday to avoid even applying for stimulus money unless the universities planned to hire people almost immediately. ''It would be the height of embarrassment,'' the official, Dr. Raynard S. Kington, said, ''if we give these grants and find out that institutions are not spending them to hire people and make purchases and advance the science the way they're designed to do.''

Businesses struggled with higher production costs last month, primarily as a result of record-high oil prices, meaning Americans might face more expensive items on store shelves soon. The Producer Price Index advanced 1.4 percent in May, its fastest pace in six months and another sign that inflation was worsening, the government said Tuesday.

When a blizzard gripped the East Coast in March, it took a wicked slice out of the economy and raised questions about the durability of the expansion. But as the weather has improved, consumers have been returning to stores -- and business executives and economists are breathing easier. "Once the weather broke, they're flocking back into the stores," said Bernard Marcus, chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, the nation's largest home improvement retailer.

Just as the American automobile industry seemed poised for a comeback after two years of slumping sales, a rapid rise in interest rates combined with sharply higher prices to deepen the gloom over Detroit. Despite the attention drawn by the Chrysler Corporation's new fuelefficent ''K'' cars and the Ford Motor Company's Escort and Lynx models last year, sales of American-made cars and trucks trailed the previous model year's. Nearly 200,000 auto workers remain out of work, the same as a year ago, and industry losses for the year are expected to total more than $4 billion -including the first annual loss for the General Motors Corporation since before the Depression. ''It's going to get worse before it gets better,'' Harvey E. Heinbach, vice president and chief automotive investment analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, said. ''It's a function of interest rates.''

LEAD: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, has privately warned an international conference of government ministers and business executives that the surge of foreign investment in the United States was creating a backlash here.

THE prices are coming down, but new homes in the United States are still not selling, and some of them are getting old while waiting for a buyer. In its report on new-home sales in March, the Census Bureau said that 189,000 completed new homes were on the market and unsold. That number was down a bit from the peak of 198,000 reached this winter, but it remains far higher than in previous cycles.

''They,'' says President Reagan at the end of the campaign, ''even drove prayer out of our nation's classrooms.'' Who are They and in any case what does forced prayer in public schools have to do with today's election? A White House spokesman explains only that ''They know who they are,'' so we're left with no idea of whom Mr. Reagan means. We've always thought that They were the Founding Fathers - who banned the official establishment of religion precisely to keep religion out of politics.

The price of gold stabilized yesterday after a sharp decline the previous day. The dollar continued to rise, aided by reports that President Reagan will end controls on oil prices. Gold has been buffeted in recent days, both by comments from Mr. Reagan and the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, that they would like lower prices and by speculation that Iran may have to sell some gold to pay war bills.

Yes, the dreaded day is here. Schoolchildren must be yanked away from the beach and the bliss of staying up late, and grown-ups must put on oh-so-solemn faces and concentrate again on the tasks at hand. Call it Labor Day + 1 -- no, make that Refocusing Day. Even if you returned from vacation weeks ago, even if you think you're up on the news, were you really paying attention? If you were, you get the Scrooge award for workaholics.

Last week's Government figures showed that more than two-thirds of the nation's economic growth in the second quarter came from rising inventories, and that spooked Wall Street more than Main Street. Rising inventories have often been an early warning sign of downturns in production and general economic trouble to come, and that is just how Wall Street interpreted the figures. Bond prices rose sharply as investors bet that the economy would weaken and undercut pressures to raise interest rates.

The nation's high unemployment rate is a result of a severe drop in demand for goods and services and is not a reflection of longer-term structural changes in the economy, a top adviser to President Obama said Saturday. The adviser, Christina D. Romer, forcefully criticized the view that long-term unemployment was here to stay. Currently, 6.5 million workers, or 44 percent of the unemployed, have been jobless for at least six months.

While most of the debate about financial overhaul legislation has focused on the impact on how big banks do business, one piece that would affect consumers directly has received little public notice: a requirement that stock and insurance brokers act in their customers' best interest. And that provision may not make it into the final overhaul plan.

BECAUSE of record-high mortgage interest rates, virtually no new construction and a shrinking rental market, the state's Annual Housing Conference chose this year to focus on possible remedies that participants said might have been overlooked in the past because they had been considered politically unacceptable. The conference, held at Wesleyan University in Middletown 10 days ago, was attended by about 300 municipal, state and congressional representatives, their staff officials, developers, attorneys, realestate agents, leaders of nonprofit agencies, insurance executives and builders. ''Out of a sense of anger,'' said Sandy Bergin, the State Housing Department official who organized the conference, ''as well as the realization that the Reagan Administration has put its priorities elsewhere, has come a belief that this may be just the right moment to look at some of these alternatives.''

What I found most dispiriting over the last month of politicking was the sight of two senior statesmen in the Republican Party -- yes, I mean you, George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole -- climbing on the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth bandwagon in its campaign to turn Mr. Kerry from war hero to craven braggart. Both former President Bush and Mr. Dole are honorable. And Mr. Bush has personal knowledge of such smears. The bomber Mr. Bush piloted was shot down in 1944. He bailed out, but the two others in the plane, Ted White and John Delaney, were killed.

Reiterating his belief that the Government's Consumer Price Index overstates inflation, the chairman of the Federal Reserve called today for an independent commission to set new cost-of-living adjustments for income taxes and benefit programs like Social Security that are pegged to the index. Roughly 30 percent of all Federal spending is pegged to the Consumer Price Index and rises with it. Personal income taxes account for 45 percent of Federal revenues and the brackets for them are also linked to the price index.

This looks like a long, hot summer for Wall Street. Fears that the global economy will worsen gripped the financial markets again Tuesday. Downbeat economic news that investors might have shrugged off in calmer times sent the broad stock market tumbling to its lowest level this year.

A BAD economy in an election year usually churns up voters looking for someone to blame. But Republican and Democratic state and local politicians in Connecticut say they are uncertain about who is going to suffer at the polls in November.

WASHINGTON -- In case you've been out of the country for the last 25 years and were afraid that nothing had stayed the same, here are some current events you may find comforting: Bon Jovi is touring. The Russians are spying on suburbia. And Democrats in Washington are squabbling over the direction of their party. The latest flare-up of Democratic disunity has to do with how the party should respond to an explosion in government debt. This is a serious policy debate, obviously, and something of a political one, too, since both sides also have in mind November's midterm elections. But in a more fundamental way, the argument over fiscal policy represents the churning of a cultural fault line that has defined and destabilized Democratic politics pretty much since the onset of the Great Society. And President Obama is only the latest Democratic Party leader to find himself tossed about in the tremors.

BASEL, Switzerland -- Central bank chiefs warned Monday that economic growth remained uneven, especially in industrial countries, as new data reinforced fears of a slowdown in Germany, Europe's biggest economy. ''There is a degree of uncertainty which is the mark of the present time,'' the European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, said in a news conference after a meeting of central bankers, held under the auspices of the Bank for International Settlements. ''Colleagues share this sentiment that we have to accept we are in a universe where there are risks.''

You cannot write them off and the blacks off and the Hispanics off and the Jews off and assume you're going to build a party on white Anglo-Saxon males over 40. There aren't enough of us left.'' As the Senator's candid interview makes clear, his list is incomplete.
